required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Cost Effectiveness and Utility of Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) and Cardiac Cath
clinical_study.official_title: Cost Effectiveness and Utility of Coronary Artery Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) in Screening for Coronary Artery Disease

brief_summary.textblock: This is a research study to determine patient preferences between two different diagnostic tests; a CT angiogram (CTA) and a catheter angiogram, both of which are used at the University to screen for and detect heart disease.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a single site study that will retrospectively and prospectively identify and enroll 100 subjects, both male and female, 18 years of age and older who undergo both coronary angiography and coronary artery computed tomography (CT), using the electronic radiology and cardiology databases. The purpose is to conduct a survey to assess their preference for either test to diagnose coronary artery disease. Subjects should be within six months of having the tests to avoid memory and recall problems.

primary_outcome.measure: Utility of CT and catheter angiography
primary_outcome.time_frame: Within 6 months of testing with CT and catheter angiography
primary_outcome.description: Utility of CT and catheter angiography was compared within patients who had both tests performed.

intervention.description: To determine patient preference for the two tests CT angiography (CTA) and catheter coronary angiography (CCA).

study_pop.textblock: Subjects who have had both CTA and Cardiac catherizations

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Subjects who have had both CTA and Coronary angiogram.
- 18 years old and older.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Under 18 years of age
- Memory Impairment:
- Stroke
- Traumatic brain Injury
- Dementia
